title: Don't surrender.
body:
Surrendering really annoys me, especially when the reason is _"We're not going to win this, just get into a new game."_
The only reason I ever accept clicking yes in the surrender vote, is when you're actually genuinely not having any fun at all. And seeming the point of a 'game' is entertainment, fun should be the goal. 

Dying twice in lane and then popping up the surrender vote every 3 minutes for the next 40 minutes, saying _"We can't win this"_ is just disgusting.
_(and in ranked there just shouldn't be the option)_

Learning to play into a losing game is an extremely valuable skill, that you just don't acquire if you always surrender as soon as the enemy team gains the upper hand.

_________________

Case in point, the screenshot shown.

This was a game I played last night.
Yes, we did lose. And that was due to a bad fight on our part at around 55 minutes. Up until then, this game could have easily gone either way.

The point is: 
Morgana never loaded in, so she was AFK from the very beginning.
Zoe, _bless her heart_, had 4 kill participation (out of 47), only did 18,000 damage (as Zoe), and only had 5000 more gold than Morgana, in a **1 hour game.**

So It was for all intents and purposes, this was a 3v5.
We didn't just hold on, we matched them head to head. 

This game could have gone any way up until around 55 minutes. 
Why? **Because we knew how to play into a disadvantage**.
We weren't in the habit of surrendering, we had done our time being steamrolled in games, and we knew how to change our play-styles to account for the situation. The surrender vote never popped up in the whole game _(not even for a remake)_.
We had so much fun, and we were so close to winning a 3v5, next time we will win because of what we learnt in this game.

So next time you pop up that vote, just think long and hard. 
Almost no game is completely unwinable, and if you do stick it out and still lose, you'll be just that much better next time you're in that situation.
_(I've come back on multiple occasions from our nexus being on 50 HP, and then winning.)_

I think that's one of the reasons you get so many one-sided steamroll games in this elo, is because a vast number of people just don't have a clue how to play into a losing game.

If i'm in a 4v5 (as the 4) their should be no reason for the enemy team to lose (unless someone is inting) i completely disagree, fun or not, if you can't win a game just ff go next, its easier to waste 15 than to waste 60, 

I played a 92 min game about 2-3 months ago, 4v5, we spent the majority of the game 20k gold under, why, because aside from me as a 7/4/39 thresh and my duo as a 1/6/45 sejuani, my team had everyone on our team inted, when we went for the ff vote, they said no, every time, 92 mins, stuck in an unwinnable game, being held hostage by 3 %%%%s is not my definition of fun, especially when the 3 %%%%s are the ones casuing the game to lose

Context
they load in, their buddy disconnects after remake vote timer, then they spend the game running it down, i get a mid with 14 deaths, and top with 23 deaths, and im stuck solo bot as thresh, we have no jg, since my duo had to consistently come bot, the enemy played with their food for the game, so we were stuck unable to surrender, and the enemies wouldn't end.

You can't play into a game that's lost because of 3 trolls, not possible, maybe if you're the mid or adc playing a hyper carry, but otherwise, that's fucking impossible, FF needs to be a vote, and if you get trolls you should legally be allowed to leave without punishment, with manual review proving that there was no point sticking around

Maybe if the gold deficit is equalish like 2-3k either side then you could play it out, but if i see a game thats going nowhere, for example an adc that runs head first into the enemy team, then blames me when he dies, even though i'm oom or not even in lane (post-back/death), or a jg with no presence (who is also getting outfarmed) there is no point in playing that, again if you're the hyper carry  and can 1v9 then go for it, but i don't feel a want to play a lost game.

Keeping in mind, i'm very analytical, i look at kda/CS/vis score/team comp/tower takedowns/etc. if i see stats (in-game, often proved right post-game) and they're sounding alarm bells, i will not bother playing the game out, unless it changes before 20 (pre 20 votes are pointless since its not majority rules)

FF > Playing it out

Im so sorry, you're going to have to say most of that again, in comprehensible language.

From what I did understand:

You're basing your ideology on assuming that winning is the primary function of the game?

It's not.

The primary function of the game (aside from being a business) is entertainment.
So as long as players are entertained, they are fulfilling the primary function of the game.
Riot doesn't care how you are entertained.
The concept of trying to win is just the easiest form that entertainment takes.

You don't play a game to win.  You play a game for fun, and it's more fun when you win.

Winning in itself, (as an isolated concept) is meaningless. 
It's like winning a coin toss, you won, but winning without context has no value attributed to it.
You can sit there flipping a coin alone in your room all day, but it doesn't matter how many times you 'win' the toss, it won't bring you any satisfaction.

It's the context (such as entertainment) that gives winning value.

You can have games that are fun where there is no concept of winning or losing, like minecraft or playing with leggo. Therefore winning is not integral to enjoyment.

In league, the 'prize' for winning, is virtual points that are themselves meaningless outside the game.  
Which means you don't go to league for the sole reason of earring the points.  Because without the context of the game, they have no meaning.

There are two things that give these virtual tokens worth.

1. Improving the quality of life in the virtual world.

2. Pitting yourself against another human being, and proving yourself better than them.

1st, If there was no interface, and league was just binary code. Winning wouldn't be fun would it? No sick borders, mastery flairs or Star Dragons.  So clearly we care about the 'quality' of the virtual landscape. So obviously winning can't be the primary goal, otherwise we would all settle for binary code.

2nd, if pitting yourself against another human and being better than them is the goal.  Surrendering completely nullifies the whole point. Because it is just admitting that you are inferior.

>The primary function of the game (aside from being a business) is entertainment.
>You don't play a game to win. You play a game for fun, and it's more fun when you win.`Winning in itself, (as an isolated concept) is meaningless. 

This concept of fun you are talking about, varies from person to person; Or even in different situations. 

* Are you playing among your friends, and the **fun **is to make each other laugh?. If so, winning dont matter as much.

* Are you playing on your own and you want to win because it give you progression. Then the kind of fun you are looking for is victory.

>_It's like winning a coin toss, you won, but winning without context has no value attributed to it.
_

This is a competitive game, you are vsing other people. The sastisfaction of victory derive from meeting your goals; Whatever it might be. Winning is an approval of one's ability, and a proof of superiority. Cointoss without a quest to aim for is as you say. worthless. 

But league is far more complex than a simple cointoss repetition. Losing has a lot of negatives than failing to land head, playing an aimless simulation. The enemy taunts , your team flaming, lost of progression, wasting time with nothing to shown for. ETC...

>You can have games that are fun where there is no concept of winning or losing, like minecraft or playing with leggo. Therefore winning is not integral to enjoyment.

Game like minecraft is a progression based game. The fun is accomplishing your objectives. If there is no target to aim for, then anything they do will seem menial and pointless.

>You're basing your ideology on assuming that winning is the primary function of the game?

Depending how industrious, and how high up in conscientiousness you are as a person. Your concept of **fun **will change. An achievement oriented person will find the concept of winning to be more important, fun come from victory. And the opposite can be said for people whose traits is the reserve; They dont care whether they win or lose. Time is aplenty and the input of efforts is low. 

It come down to personality traits, and how people see it from their point of view. There is no one size fit all. You're representing your type of people. **Not everyone**. Same goes for me.
